turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- versus Wilber M. Brucker, Individually and as -- of the Army.
Mr. Shapiro, you may continue.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
May it please the Court.
Two questions were asked to me yesterday by members of the Court which I think either, one I was unable to answer or two which I don't feel that I have answered adequately.
And I'd like to address myself first before continuing with my argument to those questions.

The first one was the question of Mr. Justice Black as to whether or not the Uniform Code of Military Justice contained a provision similar to the one with respect to conduct on becoming an officer or a gentleman for enlisted personnel.
There is such an article in the Uniform Code of Military Justice, it's the general article, Article 134.

So it seems and as a matter of fact, the case is so whole that an individual who commits a crime while he is a soldier and he gets in trouble with the civilian authorities would be subject to the court-martial jurisdiction under Article 134 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice.
Equally true is the situation where the enlisted man writes scandalous letters to his commanding officer's wife.
That too would come under Article 134 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice.
So we see that in every --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that because -- is that because the commanding officer's wife that he wrote to some civilian outside, would that make a difference?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I think it would not make any difference at all, Your Honor.
I think it would have any scandalous conduct which would reflect adversely on the Army would come within the provisions of Article 134.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Writing a private letter isn't a scandalous conduct in the ordinary sense, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't think that it would be at all.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if you have to -- he couldn't -- if he wrote a letter, private letters like that, they can't do anything about that.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I don't think that they could with â€“ under Article 134.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not suggesting they couldn't court -- they could court-martial, but they couldn't take note of the fact he is that kind of a person.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I agree with you, sir, on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, what do you agree with?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I agree that I don't think they could take notice that he was that kind of a person.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is that?
They could not.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, sir, I don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Now, I think from the answer to this question, it now becomes clear that army regulation seeks --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean they couldn't discharge him?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, sir.
They couldn't discharge him if he wrote such kind of letters.
I mean they could discharge him for any reason that they wanted but the question here is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm not reaching the question here.
I just want to know what the -- what the powers are not what the question --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I think the Army can discharge an individual for any reason it sees fit.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Just because they don't like his face.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, sir.
If they don't like his face, they can discharge him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if they discharge him because he wrote a systematically scandalous letter to private people, they could not -- they -- you said they could discharge him but they couldn't make public that fact.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I think -- well, I think the answer to that question would be that they could discharge him and they could not make public that fact.
Now, I think we can see then that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They ought to give him an honorable discharge?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I would think so, Your Honor, yes.

Now, with respect to Army Regulation 615-360, we now see that unless the man has been subject to a general court-martial, unless he has been subject to more than one special court-martial, and if he has ratings of excellent as to character and ratings of excellent as to efficiency, he must receive under 615-360 an honorable discharge with of course the exceptions spelled out in the Army security risk regulation as set up and established by Department of Defense directive 5210.9, which we are challenging here.
The second question which I would like to address myself to is the one asked to me yesterday by Mr. Justice Frankfurter.
And that question was whether or not our position in this case could be analogized to the situation of an individual who had been fired from government civilian employment.
And the question I think was whether or not it was our position that the Secretary of the Army could not make a public statement saying why the individual had been discharged.
I would agree with that position but that's not this case.
An army discharge certificate is not a notification of personnel action which terminates a federal civilian employee from his job.
An army discharge certificate, that is an honorable discharge certificate, is much more than that.
Not only does it record the fact of the separation of service but it is in the words of this court, a formal final judgment by the Government on the military record of the soldier.

And from that document comes certain very valuable rights, community respect and honor are established by it, and those rights are conclusive, property rights, rights for example to various benefits provided by the state, provided by the Federal Government, flow from that document.
And a certain kind of personal honor, a personal status of community respect and honor are inherent within the document itself.
And I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When you say inherent you mean that --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Inherent in the honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you mean is that an honorable discharge carries certain representations to the public, is that it?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, sir.
With respect --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what are those representations?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Those representations are as follows.
That during the time the individual was in the service, he comported himself honorably and he left the service in a status of honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How about the case you put earlier?
writing a lot of scandalous -- obscene letters to people.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I would say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you say that that has nothing to do with his carrying a sword and shooting and polishing his shoes et cetera, is that it?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I thought it would.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I would say if that did not come under Article 134, it could not be used to stigmatize his discharge certificate.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He may have been found cheating at cards in all powers.
I don't know whether that would be court-martial attempt, probably not, would it?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I really don't know, Your Honor, but I would think not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)
but he -- suppose it was found he done that all the time, that has nothing to do with the fact that he might be a very brave and rather even if you plea a distinguished soldier in action.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That would be proper.
Those are not inconsistent as we know about this.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Nonetheless, he would have to be given honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I would think so, Your Honor, unless he was subject to court-martial jurisdiction under 134.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, could -- could the Congress of United States take a different view of this?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I would think that they very well might but they haven't yet.

As a matter of fact, it has been our position that when Congress reenacted Article 108 of the Articles of War and now it's set forth in the present statute which is the statute of May 5, 1950, which is the reenactment of Article 108 and they reenacted it without material change.
It is our position that they -- that they incorporated all of the rulings of the judge advocate general and the attorney general of the United States within their reenactment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What your position is as I understand it yesterday and today that as a matter of statutorylimitation upon the defense services or the Army, that as a matter of statutory limitation, statutory requirement, there are only two kinds of discharges that they'd be given, one honorable and one dishonorable.
And the dishonorable discharge requires certain conviction or offenses or misconduct in the actual soldiering in its technical, narrow restrictive meaning of that word, is that right?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, Your Honor, that's not correct.
The army has the right, I think, by statute to give a number of various kinds of discharges.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Such as?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: They can give an honorable discharge, they can give a general discharge under honorable conditions, they can give an undesirable discharge, they can give a bad conduct discharge and they can give a dishonorable discharge.

The dishonorable discharge is by sentence of general court-martial, the others are through administrative regulation which have been established by the Secretary and have been within his power since the time the Articles of War were first enacted.
Now, this is the point I'm trying to get at and I think that this is really the key issue with regard to the statutory construction.
It's just this.
The Army, in issuing the kinds of discharges that they issue have to take into account and be limited by those things which are relevant to the discharge itself.

For example, a discharge certificate is not a certification by the Army, that a man was for example or was not a bank robber, before he was inducted, and it's not a certification either that he may not become a bank robber after he's released from the military service and goes into civilian life.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you're not restricting your argument as you indicated yesterday to pre-service disqualification because you said in your case there is an element of conduct under scrutiny during --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- during service.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you're now drawing a line between activities and conduct, call it what you will, what you regard as unrelated to soldiery.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you say the mere quality of his character is unrelated to soldiers.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, I say that the quality of his character is very much related to his soldiering because the Army provides a system whereby his character can be rated.
And as a matter of fact, in this particular case, wherever there were ratings as to this man's character, he was rated as excellent.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it can't show on the -- on the discharge.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In this case, we're dealing with a discharge that is general discharge with -- what is (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Under honorable -- general under honorable conditions discharge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And -- and your objection to that is that it's not explicitly stated an honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: It is not an honorable discharge.
That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And it was given in this form because the Army thought that that which took place while he was in the service or on his conduct as a soldier or his qualification as a solider or the kind of authentication the Government wanted to make which barred them, which led them to prefer general discharge under honorable conditions rather than honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I'm afraid I can't speak for my adversary, sir, but I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm talking about you.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I don't think that's the Army's position.
I think really that they found that the letters were really de minimis.
I think they were actually concerned with the conduct which predated his --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I know but --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: -- induction.
But that so far as we're concerned is not the issue.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why -- why is that not a part of the issue?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: We think that because of the two letters which he wrote, the Army could consider this as part of an overall question of conduct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How do we know that's the only reason they did it?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I wouldn't say that that was, and I couldn't speak of course for the Army.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose they did it for that reason, and they did it for other reasons, I assume other reasons that were improper for them to consider.
What is the situation?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I -- I would think that it would depend upon whether or not the conduct which occurred subsequent to induction was de minimis or not and I think that would be a question for this Court to decide on the basis of the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How could you decide it line of this general position in connection with agencies and are with verdicts of the conviction.
And if there are several reasons given, some are bad, it might not -- consequence might not have resulted and had been limited to the good reasons.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I think really, Your Honor, we're not limited to that question here for this additional reason.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- I want to talk about being limited.
I was wondering why both questions are not present in your case, maybe they are none.
So, I was wondering why both questions are not present.
Number one, whether it's legal to consider a man's past character as, I understood you to say was done here, investigated, rely on that.
Secondly, whether it's legal to consider what happened after he was in the Army.
Now, assuming that one should reach the conclusion that the discharge was justifiable on one of the two causes, how could we know that it would have occurred had they not relied on both?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, with respect to the question of findings, Your Honor, I think perhaps it might have to be sent back for a determination as to what the Army relied on.

But I really feel and it's our position in this case that the two letters that this man did write after he was inducted had nothing whatever to do with the actual character of the service he rendered.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that's your argument with reference to it as to why it was wrong to rely on it.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But do you concede it was right to rely on the other part as to what happened before he got into --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, sir.
We do not concede that all.

We say that with respect to pre-induction conduct, number one, and with conduct antedating induction, having nothing whatever to do with the character of the service, none of these factors can be considered with respect to the kind of discharged issue.
Now, let me go into the jurisdictional question for a moment, the question of this Court's power to review.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To review what?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: To review the issuance, the action of the Army in issuing this man the kind of discharge he was issued on the basic facts of this case as they stand admitted before the Court.

We think that under this Court's holding in Perkins against Elg, even if the District Court had no power to compel the Army to issue the petitioner here an honorable discharge certificate, certainly, we think it had the power to declare invalid or unconstitutional the kind of discharge he did get if the reasons for the action were invalid or unconstitutional.

Nevertheless, the respondent argues that the legislative history of the statutes providing for the Board -- the Army Discharge Review Board and the Army Board for the Correction of Military Records, demonstrate a congressional intent to preclude judicial review of this kind of case.
We disagree.

We think that the legislative history of the term "final" as used both in Section 301 of the Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944 and in 207 of the Legislative Reorganization Act, indicate that Congress did not preclude judicial review of arbitrary or capricious administrative action by the military.

Of course, if Congress had said that the administrative determination not only should be final and conclusive but that no court of the United States should have jurisdiction to review such determination, of course, the army's position would be much stronger.
But here, so far as Section 207 is concerned, such words were specifically deleted from the statute by committee amendment.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In this -- this statute and even the bill.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: From the bill, that's right, Your Honor.
Now, the second half of the Army's attempt to sidestep what we consider the basic issue here, is the contention that Harmon has not suffered injury to a legally protected right.
The Army says that since the general under honorable conditions discharge entitles Harmon to virtually all federal veterans' benefits.
He hasn't suffered the kind of injury which would give him the standing to raise the issues he seeks to raise in this case.

Now, while it's true that the general discharge will not automatically deprive Harmon of federal veterans' benefits, he will be deprived of a number of veterans' benefits provided by the laws of the State of New York.

The New York statutes make marked distinction between an honorable discharge and a discharge under honorable conditions and I call the Court's attention specifically to the Education Law of the State of New York and the distinction between Section 609 of the Education Law and Section 608 as it's discussed in our brief.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is discussed in your brief?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: It's set forth, Your Honor, at page 33 of our brief.
But we think more important than the loss of these state veterans' benefits is the stigma which attaches to anything --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Before -- before you move on to that.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understood you to say that the New York Education Law makes a distinction between an honorable discharge and a general discharge under honorable conditions.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, just a discharge under honorable conditions, they don't use the word general in the statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To make it -- what is the distinction between?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: The distinction between the two is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, what is the distinction that the New York Education Law makes?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I think Section 608 has to do with soldiers who have been -- educational benefits for soldiers who have been discharged under honorable conditions.
And Section 609 has to do with scholarships for the children of veterans who have been honorably discharged.
The types of discharge, a discharge under honorable conditions and an honorable discharge are very, very much different.
The --the army regulations themselves indicate that the general discharge is basically a substandard discharge for those who do not meet the qualifications of an honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is this discharge under honorable conditions?
When does that get into the -- in the former military law?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I think that's been in, Your Honor, since some time after the First World War, but I don't think that I'm quite sure on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that the -- what is it, regulations or -- or --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: It's established by army regulation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the New York Education Law responds to that record

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's on that distinction?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I don't think that they make that kind of distinction but I think that they've inherently made that distinction in the statute so that if the statute would be applied to Harmon's children, he would not be entitled to an educational scholarship for those children under Section 609.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I want to know is -- the New York statute take cognizance of this distinction made in the army regulations.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I think it would, Your Honor, there have been no rulings on it, but I do think they would.
Judge Frank indicated they would in the case of Schustack against Herren which was in the Second Circuit, and he thought they would.
And I think the statute shows a marked distinction between an honorable conditions discharge and an honorable discharge.
As a matter of fact, there is an Air Force regulation, Air Force Regulation 39-10 Section 3, which provides that a general discharge may be a disadvantage to an airman seeking civilian employment.

And we say that much more important than the state veterans benefits, is this stigma which attaches to anything other than an honorable discharge and much more important in Mr. Harmon's case is the fact that as a law student and perspective candidate for admission to the bar, he may find by reason of the general and honorable conditions discharge, a great deal of difficulty with the Committee on Character and Fitness for the first judicial department of that State.

Judge Bazelon in his dissent below, we think, put it very, very succinctly when he said, "But whatever may be said of the technical legal equivalence or difference between the two types of discharge from a real life point of view, they are vastly different.
The portion of our population holding honorable discharge certificates from the armed services is now so great that an adverse reflection is inherent in a certificate which is other than honorable."

This is of course confirmed by the statement of appellee's counsel in oral argument, that every soldier gets an honorable discharge unless there is some blemish on his record on account of which he receives the discharge other than honorable.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How -- how does one reach that conclusion?

I mean speaking for myself if I hadn't read that and read all this, it never would have occurred to me that the fellow has a piece of paper that he's discharged under honorable conditions, that honorable doesn't mean the same thing as an honorable discharge.
I know that isn't so but how do -- how can one be so sure that inherently there is a difference?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do honorable, do the words honorable mean different things, as -- as they're differently used?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Because the term is general, Your Honor.
It's an administrative discharge which -- I mean the normal type of discharge is an honorable discharge.
It says in big letters on it, "Honorable Discharge."
Those are the standard words which are used on the discharge certificate.
Anything other than that immediately catches the attention.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I just wonder if that --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I take notice of that as a psychological fact so I myself -- it never would have occurred as to my stupid mind.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Now, if --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There is nothing on the face of the certificate that indicates that he was discharged for security reasons.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes Your Honor and that's exactly the point I'm coming to now.
Now, it's true that the term â€œArmy Regulations 604-10â€, that's the army security risk regulation, does not apply on Harmon's discharge certificate or on his official report of separation.
However, both the Department of Defense Director and AR 604-10 itself require that the discharge certificate be so marked.
Now, since clerical mistakes --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is this not on this one?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Not on this one, Your Honor.
But --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) to it at all.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, sir.

But since clerical mistakes or omissions can always be corrected on the separation certificate even after its issue, we cannot presume unless of course this Court reverses the court below that the army will fail to correct this omission or mistake from its own -- in accordance with its own regulation, and of course the Director from the Department of Defense.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But isn't the separation certificate a different thing from discharge certificate?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it's sometimes used in lieu.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Doesn't every soldier get a summary, a brief of his war -- of his military record?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's right.
It's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's a very different thing from the discharge certificate.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Actually, no, Your Honor, it is not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: They -- they are interchangeable in this sense.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's surprising.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: The official report of separation from the Armed Forces of the United States is today given for those who are released from active military duty and placed in the inactive reserve.
They actually do not get an honorable discharge certificate until they have completed their required eight years of two years active service, six years inactive service.

So that for -- in the large part of those people who are inducted under the Universal Military Training and Service Act, they get when they are released to the inactive reserve what is know as an official report of separation, the DD Form 214, which in most cases serves in lieu of the honorable discharge.
Now here, this man was discharged before his 24 months of active military duty.
So he did get a discharge certificate as well as an official report of separation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you say he gets -- you get this 214 in lieu of a discharge?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor because --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And are you saying in that separation, in that 214, the Army can't put down why he was separated.
We haven't got that question before us at all.
But I'd suppose, unless you correct me -- unless I'm corrected that that's a very different thing from the piece of paper called a discharge.
And that gives a summary history of his -- of his military record and that is -- may be called for if he seeks to re-enlist, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
And that's exactly --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that's not this.
That's not here before us.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Oh, yes.
It is, Your Honor.
If I may -- if I may be -- presumed to say that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, if it -- but have we got that certificate (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It's set forth at 111 and 112 of the printed record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And are you also challenging the right of the Army to do that?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes we are, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't understand that.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: We say that that has -- that statement on the record has nothing whatever to do with a man's service, because in box one, the first box you come to on the official report of separation, is the box which says "Character of separation."
And it seems to us that if a man was an excellent soldier, the character of separation has got to be nothing less than honorable.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But this DD 214 isn't what the word at large seems, does it?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: It may very well, Your Honor, it's used in lieu of the actual discharge certificate.
It's the thing for example which the veterans administration uses to base its benefits on.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not saying it isn't used.
All I'm saying is I am greatly surprised.
I hadn't realized if it's to hear what the Government says that we are dealing here with the rightness of the Government to reissue 214.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: As well as the certificate itself.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Now, it seems to us that with the general discharge being subject to an identification of the type --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask something as to this?
Isn't this one document, face side is the discharge and the reverse side is the 214?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
That's the way --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Two separate documents?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: -- they have been printed, they are two separate documents.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Has that always been so or is that different?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: To my knowledge it's always been so.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So, that so also stops?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I would think so, but I think they get a different kind of a discharge certificate --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know one is (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Put in mind, the face was discharge and the reverse was just 214.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, that may very well have been but I know that for enlisted men, that they do issue two separate documents.
I have got two separate ones.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then -- but you are denying that that's the routine that they are used -- that there are normally two documents.

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: No, there are normally two documents.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, yes.
And are you saying that there can be no record made anywhere of the basis for his discharge?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: I think that the basis for the discharge is the man's military record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I understand but if he is severed because for a reason, they cannot put on record why he was severed, is that right?
If they hadn't --

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: That's correct.
Not on his discharge certificate or on his official report of separation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How about some document in the war department?

turn.speaker: david_i_shapiro
turn.label: Mr. David I. Shapiro
turn.text: They can do whatever they want with that because as far as we are concerned, that's never shown to the public.
That's not the certification that the man has.
It's not the document which gives him rights to various benefits and to what we term community respect and all.
I see that my time is up.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Shapiro.
Mr. MacGuineas.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: May it please the Court.
If I may ask the Court to turn again to page 112 of the record, which is the photostatic copy of the actual discharge certificate received by the petitioner.
This is the document which is stated to impose such horrendous consequences upon petitioner that it violates his constitutional rights.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, not his constitutional rights to the person -- as I understood Mr. Shapiro's argument is that the terms under which an honorable discharge must be given and defined by a statute and that he comes within the terms of the statute.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, as I understand it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So we may reach -- so he may not reach the consequences.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, but that is an alternative contention which he makes, I believe.
Now, the only difference in form --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You don't start with the constitutional proposition.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Oh, I certainly do not intend to, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The only difference in form and content between this general discharge certificate which petitioner holds and the honorable discharge certificate which he asked this court to compel the Secretary of the Army issue to him is the heading, first, instead of the large type general discharge would be the words "honorable discharge."
And then there is an additional statement in the honorable discharge certificate that it is awarded as a testimonial of honest and faithful service.
Now, that testimonial is omitted from the general discharge certificate and that is the only distinction in the two types of certificates upon which petitioner bases his whole case.

Now, to clarify the statements of petitioner's counsel with respect to the report of separation form, the DD 214, the original of that form is the official army record maintained in the War Department, the official record of the soldier's service.
It is a copy of that record which is given to the soldier as well as the formal discharge certificate.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: They are separate pieces, separate documents (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: As I understand it, they are separate documents.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So why is this -- I don't quite understand it.
On page 111 is -- purports to be one side of the document, on page 112 the other side, is that wrong?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, they're -- they're merely printed.
That's merely the way the printer chose to print it in the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They are two separate pages?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Completely separate documents.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. MacGuineasm, you minimize the difference between this discharge and an honorable discharge and I think it strange that Mr. Shapiro would -- would urge that there is a great difference.
What is the difference and -- and why do you have the two -- two forms of discharge if you please?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The difference is, both are given under honorable conditions, they represent that the solider has served under honorable conditions.
But the honorable discharge certificate is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, wait a minute.
Do they -- they served under honorable condition, is it --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- is it -- do both of them mean that he served honorably?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, the -- the official phrase in the army regulations is served under honorable conditions and that I take it means honorably whether the discharge is the honorable discharge or the general under honorable conditions.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In other words, both of them say that he served honorably while in the armed forces?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: They say he served under honorable conditions.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I know.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- that's the exact language of the certificate.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you were -- you were trying to minimize the difference between these two discharges.
What I want to know is, does the general discharge import that he served honorably in the Army?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, surely.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Precisely.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's all I want to know.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is the distinction then?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The distinction is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You are not there to contend or do you contend they mean the same thing?
And if they mean the same thing, then why not use the same phrase?
And if they don't mean the same thing, what is the difference?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: They -- legally, they mean the same thing as I hope to develop at length in the argument.
The honorable discharge is an accolade, if I may say so, a highest type of letter of recommendation.
The general discharge, while it says the man has served under honorable conditions, does not get in that extra accolade and that's the only non-legal distinction between the two.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'll have -- how old is the second type (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The -- the general discharge under honorable conditions as such was introduced into the army regulations in 1921.
The history of that is set forth in a footnote in our brief.
It's in --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How -- how old is the other?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The honorable discharge?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, I think that goes back to the beginning of our military organization.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What percentages of -- of discharge servicemen get the accolade?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, we had in a footnote in our brief a compilation of the number of discharges given over the last several years by the Army and the Air Force.
Discharges other than the honorable discharge.
And as the court can see that runs up to from 20, 25, 30, up to 40,000 per year.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What page is that in your --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That's page 38 of our main brief, Your Honor.
The table there -- for instance, the -- the highest number shown is for the year 1954 when some 39,000 were given.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And is this general discharge rated in the classification number awarded less than the honorable discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, now of course, it must be understood that that doesn't mean that it's not a discharge under honorable condition as we've --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: We merely have to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's properly classified there as being a discharge lest anomalous.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, I think it might have been more artistic if it had said, number awarded a discharge other than the honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, who -- who put this classification?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, that's the -- I think we did.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that in the army reports when they --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that in the army reports?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, no.
This is a -- this is purely a tabulation which we prepared from army statistics and air force statistics prepared by us.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then, you think probably you are wrong in saying that is less than an honorable discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I think it might have been phrased more artistically to say other than an honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Some place in the -- in the briefs, I -- I thought I saw that 95% of all servicemen received the accolade, is that -- is that correct?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, the -- the figures are given in this table on page 38.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, but they -- but they don't say in percentages.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it -- is that approximately true that 95% of the --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That's a rough approximation.
I would think that is true.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
And what approximation will get a dishonorable discharge or a bad discharge of any kind, do you know?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I am sorry.
Neither the record nor the briefs contain that information.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Must be a sizable number, isn't it?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, the Court knows that there is substantial number of court-martials every year.
What that number amounts to, I'm just not in a position to say.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

Well, the point -- point is simply this that in my mind, that if 95% get an honorable discharge, what you call the accolade, and a large number of them get dishonorable discharges and -- and discharges below even the one that this man got, the number of this kind of discharges is apparently very small, is very, very small.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, in terms of the overall total of discharges, it certainly is.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, all right.
Now -- now why -- why would that small number of men be -- be denied the honorable discharge?
I just want to know --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- what -- what caused it and why you do it and what the necessity for -- for the two different kinds are if you want the public to believe that this general discharge is the equivalent of an honorable discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Will You Honor permit me to lead up that to that answer?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, yes, in your own way.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, thank you.

As we read 175 years of legislative practice in this country running back to before the revolution, Congress has never intended to vest in the civil courts discretion to decide what types of discharges shall be prescribed by the armed forces, that is to say what categories of discharges, nor has it attempted to vest the courts with jurisdiction to decide what established form of certificates shall be given to a particular soldier under any particular circumstances.
The British Articles of War at the time of the revolution required that a soldier be given a discharge.They did not specify honorable or dishonorable or other types of discharge.

That has been carried forward through the continental Congress in the Articles of War and after the Constitution was adopted through the early Congresses in the Articles of War and it has been carried forward to date.
Specifically, the statute which is applicable to petitioner's discharge is an Act of 1920 which provides that no --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That may be found at the back of our main brief, Your Honor, at page 78, paragraph number two.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: This is the basic statute of this.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: This is the basic statute under which the discharge was given to petitioner.
And the Court --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is this -- is this the only one to which we need look --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, I will --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- for the authority for this particular discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I will in a moment refer to one other subsequent statute.
But the Court will observe that under that statute, first, every enlisted man must, upon his discharge, be given a certificate of discharge.
And secondly, that no enlisted man shall be discharged prior to expiration of his term except in the manner prescribed by the Secretary of the Department of the Army or by court-martial.

Note again that Congress, even to this date, has never specified whether there shall be honorable discharges, general discharges, undesirable discharges or so forth, nor has it ever set forth the conditions under which the man receives one type of discharge rather than another.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Have there been regulations which have the effective law --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which you have that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: And that is my point, that Congress has left in the military establishments, the full discretion to prescribe by regulation, what types discharge that shall be and under what circumstances a particular type shall be given to a particular soldier.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, was Harmon discharged before his term of service expired?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
So this statute has direct application to petitioner.
Now, the only other statute which has direct application to petitioner is -- is the following paragraph on page 78 of our brief.
The Universal Military Training and Service Act.
And -- and when that Act was enacted, there was the Secretary of Defense, super imposed upon the three military establishments.

So it provides that no soldier shall be discharged prior to expiration of his term of service except in accordance with procedures prescribed by the Secretary of Defense, which I take it means super imposes a general discretionary authority of the Secretary of Defense upon the Secretary of the Army.
But Congress again had stayed completely away from the whole problem of what types of discharges there shall be and how -- and under what circumstances they shall be given.

Now, in the Armed Forces Reserve Act of 1952 which is directly applicable to the next case to be argued, the Abramowitz case, there is a similar provision providing for discharge in accordance with regulations promulgated by the appropriate Secretary of the military establishment.
Now, Mr. Justice Black asked about the regulations.
And the types of discharges have been for generations prescribed by the heads of the military departments.
At the present time and at the time applicable in this case, there were five types of discharges given by the army.
The first, the appellate as I put it is the so called honorable discharge.
The second, the one which petitioner received is the general discharge under honorable conditions.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Are the regulations covering these different categories of discharges printed in your brief?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes -- yes, Your Honor.
They are described in general terms in page -- at page 32 of our brief, with a general indication of the different circumstances under which each type of discharge becomes appropriate.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, do you -- do you quote the -- the regulation under which the general discharge is issued?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, we do not set that forth in text Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why not?
Isn't it -- isn't it a very important thing in this case?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, I think it might have been well to do that, I regrettably --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You can still do it.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: But we -- I will be happy to supply the Court with -- with verbatim printed copies of the regulation itself if that would be --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, can you read it to us now?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That to me it's very important to know if you've got a regulation for -- for an honorable discharge and another regulation for a general discharge and you're claiming that he's only entitled to a general discharge, and the other side is claiming he is entitled to an honorable discharge, seems to me elementary that should -- it had both those regulations in this -- in this record some place where we could -- where we could read them.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.
They -- they are set forth by petitioner in his brief in part at page 52 of the petitioner's brief.
Now, if -- if the Court wishes to turn to paragraph eight, near the bottom of page 52.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that the controlling one here?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, not that sole paragraph.
It is an applicable one but there are others that have bearing on the question.

But counsel for petitioner has pointed out that under paragraph eight of that regulation, a soldier gets the honorable discharge if his character and efficiency ratings have been very good and excellent, and he has not been convicted by court-martial, except as otherwise provided in the regulations.

Now, of course here, there is an except as otherwise provided because the reference there to paragraph 13, except as provided in these regulations and pertinent regulations listed in paragraph 13, paragraph 13 is regrettably not printed by either side, but I have it here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, why is it --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why isn't it printed, Mr. -- it seems to me that that's a very vital elementary in this case.
Why shouldn't we have it?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, I -- I -- of course, I agree the Court should have it and I suggest that perhaps the most convenient form would be for us to submit the -- the official printed form of the regulation itself.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would you agree -- would you agree that if in fact without any controversy about the underlying fact establishment, if in fact a claim is made that a discharged soldier comes within a particular regulation and he has been denied what the face of the regulation entitled him to that he could enforce that regulation even in a court of law.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, I do not agree with that, and that leads me --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I hope you get my question.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I hope I do too, and I think I do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: My question is, if in contesting, a person comes within a regulation promulgated by the army, they say any person is valid by the one, two, three condition, comes within this regulation rather than that, you can enforce that regulation provided there is no controversy as to where they comes within that regulation.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: And Your Honor means enforce it in the civil courts?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The regulation says that he is entitled to this kind of a discharge.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He says I am -- I come within those terms and the War Department comes in and says, "Yes, he comes within those terms, but we have chosen not to enforce that regulation."
You say even then there is no resort to the civil authority?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I do for the reason.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I just want to know.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: For the reason that Congress has provided an alternative system of justice to take care of that in similar situations.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How could he enforce that regulation?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: He enforced it first by applying to the Army Discharge Review Board.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know the -- he goes through the whole thing and the Secretary for the Army, let me suppose, an unfair situation.
Everybody along the line disregard, says, "Yes, he comes within this regulation but we are not going to give him the benefit of it."

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He then enforces it in the court of law --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: We say no.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, all right.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: We say no.
We say that Congress with finality said, "If this situation arises, we will give the solider a remedy within the service department and that's the end of it."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I am suggesting he exhausted all of them.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I understand but I am saying that what Congress said was that's the end of it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask just one more question to be sure in the influence.

Suppose of what you say -- suppose the army had said yes, we discharged him -- we discharged him because we didn't like his religion, to give him a discharge less than honorable, could he go to court?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Even in that extreme, in fact almost unimaginable case, we would say that he could not because Congress does not intend that there shall be a legal right in the justiciable sense to a particular type of discharge.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: However arbitrary the action of the army may be?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: However, precisely because --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No matter how extreme we may suppose a case of arbitrary and capricious action.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He has no remedy in the court of law.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Exactly.
In our view, Congress has --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are you going to establish that?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I certainly hope so.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I'd be very delightful from hearing it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that what this case is about?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, that is an element.
Certainly, that is an important element in this case.
Now, the statute which set up the Army Discharge Review Boards provided that the discharge given should be final subject only to review by the Secretary.
That is one instance of a congressional statement of finality.
And further more in 19 --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that â€“ Is that always a statement of that kind always preclude judicial review?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No.
Every finality clause should be read in the light of its history.

And we say here that this finality clause is to be read in that light for the historical reason that traditionally from the beginning of our Government Congress has left it wholly up to the service departments as to what discharge soldier John Jones gets.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I suggest that there is no case to correct you, but I suggest there is no case which worries you or calls upon you to take the position as they did.
No case in which the extreme limits of military authority and non-interference by the civil authority has been recognized that warrants the statement that you made because no situation has been --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- presented to the Court.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I quite agree that that the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And why do you argue such an extreme position of what you don't have --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, I was answering Your Honor's contention.
The suggestion --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but there are various ways of answering

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- that if that occurred --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: One way of answering is that I am not qualified to take a position for the Government in the situation that it support.
That's one way of answering.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: What Your Honor is now suggesting if I understand you is that probably no secretary of war has been so wholly arbitrary --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That isn't what I am suggesting at all, I am suggesting that a lawyer with the responsibility of the seriousness that confronts the Government in this case need not take the extreme position that the record doesn't call for.
That's what I am suggesting.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the main basis of the argument in your brief, isn't it?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The main -- our -- our first contention is that Congress has left to the military establishments the only course of redress for situations which may arise and has provided to administrative tribunals within each military establishment for that expressed purpose.
Well, if it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What case -- what case of ours do you rely on both instance?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, this that -- that precise case has not been decided by this Court.
In Patterson versus Lamb, this court expressly said it was not passing.
Your Honors' opinion by the way said you are not passing on the question as to whether the civil court had any jurisdiction to review the military discharge given.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well if Congress has done that, I suppose you would agree that there might be a constitutional question whether in the case of an arbitrary action such as I put to you, there was a denial at least to due process.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I do not think so, Your Honor.
And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you are going to argue that too?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: If, if Your Honor [Laughs] --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Argue that constitutional question?
Whether -- whether Congress has power to leave all military matters to the military authorities, you are going to argue that question in this case too?
What else aren't you going to argue?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I will argue any question which a Justice ask me to argue.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that is my notion of your responsibility if I may say so.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: But of course in the cases which have come before this Curt and the lower courts, in large part, they have been habeas corpus reviews of court-martial proceedings.

And the test there which the Court has laid down is that if it is conceded that the man is in the military establishment and if it is conceded that the court-martial which tried him was constituted in accordance with law and it had jurisdiction to pass on the offense with which he was charged, that's the end of it.

That for considerations of army discipline, the fact that the military establishment is an entirely separate community, as this Court has put it, from the civil community, that -- and for separation of powers consideration that the courts do not at all take the same type of review of military action as they do of course of governmental action which affects civilian rights.

And piecing together all of those things, the consistent course of congressional action, the extremely limited review which this Court has given even in the habeas corpus case where a statute expressly confers upon this Court -- pardon me, and on the District Courts, jurisdiction in habeas corpus.

Taking all of those things together, we consider that Congress did not intend to make the matter of a man's discharge the kind of a legal right which was proper subject matter for the civil courts to pass on.
Now, Congress has recognized the distinction between the various types of discharges in this sense.
The so-called punitive discharges, the bad conduct and the dishonorable discharges may, under the Uniform Code of Military Justice, only be given by sentence of court-martial.

In other words, that is a form of punishment imposed upon the soldier where he has been found guilty of a violation of offenses formerly prescribed by the Articles of War and now carried forward into the Uniform Code of Military Justice.

But on the other hand, the so-called administrative types of discharge, the honorable discharge, the general discharge under honorable conditions and the undesirable discharge, those are not given for the commission of offenses in the same sense at all.

They are not given because the man has been found guilty by a court-martial offense, they are given because the army has decided that from the standpoint of the efficient operation of the army, it's better off not to have Private John Jones in the Army.
Now, the general discharge under honorable conditions which is given here is given for many things which have nothing whatever to do with security considerations.
It's specifically given, for instance, if the soldier lacks physical stamina.

It's given if he is psychologically ill-equipped for combat conditions, and many other thing, it is merely a determination of the Army, that although the man has served under honorable conditions for one reason or another and may be wholly beyond his fault or anything that he can correct, the Army is just better off not to have that man in the service.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that true even though his character is rated as excellent and his performance is rated as excellent?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, tell me please how you justify that under this regulation eight as it appears on page 52 and regulation nine as it appears on page 53 of the brief for petitioner which you just --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- which you just --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I justify it because paragraph eight of that regulation starts out by saying except as prescribed by the regulations with specific reference to paragraph 13.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Where do we get that one, I have been looking for it and can't find it.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Which?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: It's seems to me that's the bottom of your whole case.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Paragraph 13.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Where is it?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: As I say, regrettably, neither side has printed that and that's what I have suggested that I will submit the complete regulation --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You have it that way -- you have it that way, you could read it to us --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- unless, it's too long.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Paragraph 13 is headed separation prior to expiration of period of service.
