When discharged or released from active military service is to be effected prior to expiration of enlistment, inductment or period for which ordered into active military service, it will be accomplished under whichever is appropriate of the following regulations, and then it gives the various numbered army regulations and the general subject a) homosexual, b) disability, c) disability existing prior to entry on active service, d) marriage and pregnancy and various other things including convenience of Government, misconduct, unfitness, inaptitude or unsuitability, disloyal or subversive.
In other words --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Which one does this fall under?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, this -- this particular edition of this regulation was issued prior to the now current regulation dealing with security.
But in the current edition of the regulation, that is listed under paragraph 13 which is the Army Regulation 604-10.
And that is the regulation by which the Army has proscribed a security standard.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I don't follow this, Mr. MacGuineas.
Is this 605-10 --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- or whatever it is, a supplement or amendment to 13 or what?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, you see --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that cited -- is that quoted in your brief?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That doesn't govern this case, does it?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

604-10 is the regulation applicable which sets forth the grounds on which petitioner was dismissed to wit that the Secretary of the Army concluded that his retention in the service was not clearly consistent with the national security.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Where is it (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, if Your Honor will turn to the -- the record at page 33, you will find set forth Department of Defense Directive number 5210.9.
That was the initial statement promulgated by the Secretary of Defense.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is that 614?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, then 604-10 was later promulgated.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is it in the record or in your brief?
If it's to knowing, why -- why this --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: It's not in your brief.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, I'm sorry to say that it has not been set forth in the brief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That is not in the record.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: It is not in the record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why isn't it in the brief?
I ask you once more.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I asked about each of these because it -- it seems to me that it's so unusual that the Government would not print in its -- in its briefs a statute that it wants us to rely upon in a case of this -- case of this kind.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The statutes are printed, Your Honor.
You mean the regulations, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The regulations, yes.
We can get the statutes very easily but the regulations are a little more --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- difficult to get.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I quite agree that the brief should have been more complete in that respect and I do not like --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But it really is a brief without that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- because it -- those are the things you rely upon with your offices.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I do not like to disclaim any personal responsibility but perhaps the Court will permit me to call the attention to the fact that my name is not on the Government's brief.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I would think you take some comfort in that.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeal both the --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeals invoke that withholding regulations?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: If Your Honor has the briefs in the next case, number 141.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I'm just asking that the Court of Appeals had decided this case, referred to that regulation, what you say is controlling.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, the Court of Appeals referred to Department of Defense Directive 5210-9.
Now, the explanation for that as I understand it, and this is a point on which petitioner has never brought forward.
The -- the Department of Defense Directive 5210.9 was promulgated in April of 1954.
That same month, petitioner was given his first discharge, the then undesirable discharge.
Up to that time, the army had not promulgated its implementation of the Department of Defense Directive.
That implementation is Army Regulation 604-10.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean what --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: It is --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What -- what you say is controlling, had not been promulgated by the Army at the time the man was discharged?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: We -- we take the -- we take the position that the Department of Defense Directive in itself was sufficiently self executing so to speak, that it would justify action by the Army even in advance of the promulgation of its formal security regulation.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then, that's what I asked you before.
Is it that you're suggesting that the 604-10, I gather now that this -- whatever the other one was, I'm so confused about all this now.
But my understanding is that as to the Department of Defense, security regulation is appropriate, upon which you justify the action taken as to Harmon.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, that -- that was directive --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, is that done by reason of an argument that, that somehow amends the regulation 9 as to general discharges or the regulation of 8 as to honorable discharges?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, that defense directive represented the promulgation of a new policy with respect to discharges, to wit a specific basis for discharging a man because his retention in the service was not deemed to be clearly consistent with the national interest.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well now, that argue then that completely independent of the regulations 8 and 9, governing honorable and general discharges.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, this --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This policy of itself justifies what was done without reference to those regulations?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: This regulation or this directive, I beg your pardon, states that the type of discharge given under this directive shall be in accordance with the character of the derogatory information against the man.
In other words, it -- the type of discharge might vary depending upon the judgment of the Secretary of the Army as to how serious the case against him was.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. MacGuineas, at the risk of repetition, would you be good enough to state categorically what materials statutory regulatory directive were in existence at the time that this discharge was issued?
Thus, give me the --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- reference.
If you're not -- didn't you say you haven't prepared this brief, you must have been -- you're not speaking to the brief when you're speaking to your own preparation.
Now, what materials underlay what relevant controlling materials or authorizing materials were in existence when this discharge was issued?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I'll be glad to do that, Your Honor, but may I point out that there were two discharges issued in this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't care what -- all right I mean the one that's before us because I take it the other one is displaced.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Good, then at the time -- it -- when the Court is considering the last discharge as being the only one in effect, that is the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't know what others may think, but for me that's the question before the Court.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I agree.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I'm interested in the first one too so I suggest that you tell us what was in existence when the first one came up and then what was in existence --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The tempering.
(Inaudible) you're talking about.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But at this confusion when we haven't got the documents.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I shall proceed chronologically.
At the time that petitioner was given his first discharge which was an undesirable discharge, the applicable statute was the Act of 1920 quoted in our brief.
The administrative regulation applicable and the only one applicable at that time was Department of Defense Directive 5210.9.
But when the Army later conducted a general review --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Pardon me, that's the one that's printed in page 52 of the petitioner's brief, is that right?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The -- the directive is in the

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That's in the record itself.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Page 33 of the record.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Page -- beginning at page 33 of the record.
And that is the only administrative regulation which was in effect at the time of the first discharge.

But subsequently after this lawsuit was in process, the army undertook a general review of all cases going back several years, of all cases of soldiers who had been dismissed under the so-called security program.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well now, had he -- had this man been dismissed at that time?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, he was dismissed and then --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you -- you said you were going to take it chronologically and -- and there were only -- only these two, eight and nine of the regulations plus this directive at the time he was discharged.
The time he got the --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No.
Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- undesirable discharge.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: At the time he got the undesirable discharge, the only -- the only regulation in effect was the Department of Defense Directive 5210.9 in the record at page 33.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: At that time the Army had not yet promulgated its implementing regulation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Now -- now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Were -- were there no regulations enforced at the time defining categories of discharges at that time?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Oh, yes, surely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well aren't they relevant?
You said a minute ago -- a few minutes ago --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- this goes back to the beginning of things where the beginning of things gave authority for promulgating regulations, so the regulatory system becomes relevant throughout our history.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, the regulation in effect at that time which set forth the conditions under which different types of discharges would be given was the one to which I previously referred Army Regulations 615-360.
And that is the one that I said provided for a discharge for a lack of physical stamina, psychological unsuitability and -- and many other things.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Were there any event that provided for discharges for conduct which would reflect discredit on that soldier --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- over this court martial?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I beg your pardon, what did you say about court-martial?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Were there any of those grounds in that statute, in that regulation, to authorize discharges of the kind that would reflect discredit on the character of the solider otherwise, other than those which provided the court-martial?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, a homosexuality is an example.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was -- was it provided that he should have a trial of any kind, to be convicted of --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No that's the whole point.
These administrative discharges are not given as a consequence of a conviction of any offense prescribed by the Articles of War.
They merely represent the judgment of the Secretary of the Army that we feel were better off not to have John Jones in the army --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that, but because the question, he is a homosexual there, what proof?
Whose judgment was obtained on that besides the Secretary of the Army?
What did the man have to do with it?
Was he given a trial of any kind before that was put on his record?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, no, not -- not in the trial in the sense that Your Honor is speaking of it, he was not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm talking about any kind of --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- any kind of the hearing such as a man would want who was charged with a very serious thing of that kind.
You mean that the army, Secretary of the Army could just say we don't want him, he is a homosexual without proof, without anything else, with no review of him.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, the review since 1954 has been provided both before the Army Discharge Review Board, where the man does have a full opportunity for a hearing and also if he's turned down there, he goes to the Board for Correction of Military Records, where he also has the second opportunity for a full hearing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's since 1954.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Since 1944.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The Army Discharge Review Board was established by statute passed in 1944.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. MacGuineas, I should think it would help the Court if you told it the history of this discharge without honor which has an important history, well-known in the history of this country, namely the discharge of a whole regiment by the Commander in Chief, President Theodore Roosevelt in the case -- in the Brownsville soldier's case.
Why do you argue this case, all of the abstract, as though that is a sudden new thing without a large practical history behind it and a judicial history?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, I -- I thought I indicated that the particular form of honorable discharge under general conditions goes back to 1921, I believe it is, and it is true that prior to that time, there were other forms of discharge given by the military service which was not the honorable discharge and yet was not a dishonorable discharge, an intermediate form of discharge.That sort of thing goes back at least to the Civil War and the -- the precise characterization of the discharge has changed in accordance with change in regulations from time to time.
Now, if I may --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And with -- with the Chief Justice's permission, may I suggest that when you submit that in print, the materials that are relevant for the understanding of this case in determination of it, you indicate what materials meaning by that statute regulation directive were in existence at the time of the first piece of paper, the undesirable discharge and what were in existence at the time of the second discharge.
So we keep these things apart and know what was before the authorizing authority, if they had authority, at the time that they acted as they did.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, with the Court's permission, we will submit a brief supplemental memorandum stating those facts and attaching as exhibits printed copies of all the regulations which are not set forth either in the record or in the briefs.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you agree that the type of discharge the army was entitled to give this man at the time he was discharged is governed and has to be governed by the law as it existed at the time he was discharged?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. -- Mr. MacGuineas, now let me see if I follow you.
You said I think that there were two discharges of Mr. Harmon.
Well now, the first was a mere transfer to another department, was it not?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: No, pardon --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And he was -- was he not first given the undesirable discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Pardon me, Your Honor.
He was first given an undesirable discharge but that was not the question of the transfer, that is the situation which occurs in the next case, in the Abramowitz case.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: All right.
This -- this man got first an undesirable discharge, then while the case was pending in the Court of Appeals, the discharge was administratively changed to less than honorable condition or to do --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: General.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: An Honorable condition.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Under honorable condition.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: All right now, do you not then say that the first discharge was under army Directive Number 5210.9, which was before the formation of the formal regulations on April 10, 1954 which became Regulation 604.10?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that the Court of Appeals dealt with only the directive which was 5210.9

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yes.
Now, and then at the time of the discharge, the first one under which the undesirable discharge was given, the long fact was the Act of 1920 and the directive number 5210.9.
At the time of the second discharge which was the one under honorable conditions, the army had formulated its formal regulations and they were 604.10, is that what you're telling us?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do you claim that -- do you argue, this man was discharged undesirable, this (Inaudible) separate from the Amy referred, whatever period of time it was, could be subjective, the kind of discharge that was not authorized in the statue.

It was only authorized in the later regulation, or do you say -- do you agree that the army, whenever it formalizes discharge, had to be governed by the law that was in existence at the time it actually put him out of the army.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I agree to that but of course, whatever the army did in connection with the first discharge, whether it be right or wrong is now out of the case, because the first discharge has been wiped out and he now has the general discharge.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that, but -- but in the general discharge, the second discharge, determining whether the statute authorized that kind of discharge.
We have to be governed, do we not, by the law that was in effect when they put him out of the army, not by the law as it was changed thereafter.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, what I -- my -- of course, my basic point is that that is not a matter of which the District Courts that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if -- if we have done -- the Army had --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: --to be governed, --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- did it not --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- by the law as it existed and the regulations as they existed when they separated from the service, not when they gave him the second discharge.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, except that that fact is immaterial in this case because they did give him a second discharge.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. -- Mr. MacGuineas, I -- I -- under those circumstances, I can't get away from -- from number 8, regulation 8 of 52 of petitioner's brief and regulation 9 on the next page.

Now, 8 says that except as provided in these regulations and pertinent regulations listed in paragraph three, an honorable discharge certificate will be furnished when the individual meets the following qualifications.
One, as character ratings of at least very good.
Has efficiency ratings of at least excellent.
Three, has not been convicted by a general court martial, and four, has not been convicted more than once by a special court martial.

Now, number 9 says, general discharge, individuals discharged under honorable conditions which do not qualify them for an honorable discharge will be furnished a general discharge except as provided below and then below they make exceptions where they can even give them a general -- an honorable discharge under those circumstances.
Now, I want you if you will please, to read me the language of any statute which govern his case at the time he was released from service in the Army.

You say it isn't relevant, the kind of discharge he got when he was separated from the service, but I want to know what conditions -- under what conditions he was discharged and I want to know the statutory or regulatory power that you rely on to vary these two regulations.
Now, read it to me please --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- so I don't --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I read from --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- have it in my mind.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I read from our brief at page 23, a quotation from the Act.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: A quotation from the Act of June 4, 1920 which was the statute in effect at the time and was applicable to petitioner's situation.
At the very bottom of the page 23, beginning --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- "No enlisted person lawfully inducted into the military service of United States shall be discharged from said service without a certificate of discharge and no enlisted person shall be discharged from said service before his term of service has expired, except in the manner prescribed by the Secretary of the Department of the Army or by sentence or court martial."

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

Now, what -- what does that statute refer to other than regulation 8 under for honorable discharges and regulation nine regulating general discharges, what -- what in the regulations vary from those two sections?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: At the time the petition was given his first discharge --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- which Your Honor is referring to.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: When he was separated from the service.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The -- the very interest, and I may use Your Honor's word, was Department of Defense Directive 5210.9.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Now, what did -- what did that -- what language do you rely on as varying this number nine, so as to warrant the Department of the Army giving him a general instead of an honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I want to hear the language.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The language would be the very opening of the paragraph eight except as provided in these regulations.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Now, where in the -- what in the regulations do you rely on, please read me that.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, at that time, the time of his first discharge, and the only regulation was the Department of Defense directives which we have referred --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- which prescribed a security risk program for the armed services.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, where did you say they could what they did here in that regulation?
Which part of that in that directive?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: In the directive?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)
which part of that directive you rely on?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: If Your Honor will turn to the directive which is in the record at page 33, begins on 33.

And the -- if you turn on to page 34, and you notice the purpose is to apply to military personnel the criteria for security programs established as national policy for civilian personnel by Executive Order 10450.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where does it say anything about discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In the discharging here.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That is on -- further over.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Page 43?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: On page -- page 43, paragraph five.
If I may skip to the end of that paragraph, "He shall be separated and the character of the separation shall be predicated upon the gravity of the reasonably substantiated information in derogation."

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, what does that say about discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, character of the separation means --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On page 43?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, paragraph five in the middle of the page.
Means that he shall be --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, does it say anything about his discharge?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, the character of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

what kind of discharge a man -- does it authorize in any way departure from the traditional discharge with the Army since the first day it started to function, for non-honorable discharge for a man who's -- who's honorably served in the Army?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does that show any -- any departure, right of department?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I am not able to accept Your Honor's generalization that even prior thereto, every man who served honorably in the army got an honorable discharge.
A man can serve honorably in the Army and yet he didn't have the physical stamina --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why certainly but --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- to be of service.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that wouldn't reflect --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- yet he didn't get an honorable --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That wouldn't reflect on his honor, the fact that he was weak, he got sick.
I'm talking about the honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: That's my point.
Such a man --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It is imposed to be the most sacred thing a man from the Army gets.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: And that's my point, such a man.
Purely because of his -- his physical weakness does not get the honorable discharge.
That's just my point.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But here's a man who had no physical weakness, it's an issue in this case, but he did have an excellent character and had an excellent performance record according to the records of the Army.
Now, what is it that shows ---

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that you can give a man of that kind less than an honorable discharge which you give to 95% of all the men who go through the armed forces of this government.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Your Honor, that -- that statement which is what petitioner's counsel made is not an accurate statement of petitioner's army record.
What he had was findings of excellence for fitness and character up until the time that the army started the proceedings which led to his discharge.
But for the period of the last few months of his military service, he did not have such a rating.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, they -- they cut him off just like they cut him off from an honorable discharge apparently.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, but I -- I thought Your Honor was -- I merely wanted to correct the record in that respect.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How long was he -- how long did they say that his conduct was unknown?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Approximately 18 -- oh, his conduct was unknown?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well isn't that what you determine he --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Yes, that's the last six weeks or so of his service --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- just prior to his dismissal --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- when these proceedings were undertaken.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I -- I read here in -- in Subdivision B of number 8, "Ratings of unknown and ratings for periods of less than two months are not disqualifying."
Now, if this was only for six weeks, why didn't he come under that?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Well, that's true within the terms if the man comes under paragraph eight.
But of course if he comes under the exception set forth in paragraph eight, then that provision has no application.
That talks about the circumstances under which you will get an honorable discharge if you are under paragraph eight.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, they -- they're all under paragraph eight or under nine --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Except as -- except --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Except as it may be modified.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: -- as otherwise prescribed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: And that's the point.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But is there anything in 13 that would indicate that ratings of unknown are not disqualifying?
What in 13 --

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: 13 doesn't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What -- what in 13 would indicate that there is any -- any retreat from that statement that ratings of unknown and ratings for periods of less than two months are not disqualifying?

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: Because 13 provides other grounds for discharge and as to which as I understand it, the -- the Army man's formal rating is immaterial.
In other words, a man might have been rated by his commanding officer as excellent and yet the army discovers that he is a homosexual.
He nonetheless maybe discharged under their exception regulation without being given an honorable discharge.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that was then in existence at the time this man was given an undesirable discharge.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: The only thing in existence was 5210.9.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: donald_b_macguines
turn.label: Mr. Donald B. Macguines
turn.text: I -- I regret that my time has expired.

I shall not have the chance to discuss our alternative point that even under the particular circumstances of this case, there is no justiciable controversy and that there is no legal injury resulting from the issuance of the general discharge to the petitioner, but that is discussed in our brief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, sir.
